I think a brief update is due regarding my attempts at refining the prey 
capture search. If you recall I was working on the idea of a buffer of 
failed/difficult test cases, e.g. waiting for a genome to score 100/100 
and then running that champion  through 10000 test cases, storing the 
cases that failed in a buffer(max size 50). This buffer then became part 
of the evaluation, thus if the buffer was full (50 cases) then I 
performed another 50 random test to make up 100, thus keeping the same 
maximum fitness throughout evolution - which keeps everything simple. 
Upon finding a genome that scores 100 I repeat the process until the 
10000 test cases are all passed, at which point evolution is complete, 
or we progress to the next difficulty level. My implementation of prey 
capture as you may recall utilises incremental evolution, so the 
difficulty level is increased in steps (0 to 11) by incerasing the prey 
speed.

The test case buffer idea is currently on hold because I realised that 
there was a flaw in this approach when combined with my evaluation 
routine. The problem was that on every evaluation I generated 100 random 
tests cases, so that the test cases from one eval to the next were 
different. In turn this means that some genomes can get 'lucky' with the 
set of test cases they receive, and therefore score above their actual 
fitness level. E.g. if I take a champ that has scored 100/100 and pass 
it through a large set of tests to get an accurate fitness level it 
typically had a fitness level of 91-92%.

So when I implemented the idea of a test case buffer the champ genome 
would typically fail the 10000 test cases, the buffer would be filled 
and then immediately on the next generation a champ would pass all test 
cases in the buffer but fail on the next round of 10000 random test 
cases. This cycle would continue ad infinitum.

So right now I am experimenting with evaluating against 100 fixed test 
cases. They are still generated randomly, so hopefully they represent a 
good spread of test cases, but they are the same 100 cases on each 
evaluation. This approach results even worse champ genomes, with actual 
fitness arounf the 87-88% mark. However I can improve this figure by 
increasing the number of evaluations, e.g. if I perform 1000 test per 
eval the figure comes out at around 99%+, unfortunately this is a 
measurement from a lower difficultly level, I have yet to evolve a champ 
at the highest level, but I think the figure is indicative of what can 
be expected.

I know that Derek wanted to avoid increasing the number of test cases 
per eval. because it does eat up more CPU time, but what I want to do is 
go back to the idea of a test case buffer with a small number of 
difficult test cases, but this time with a fixed set of 'random' test cases.

Also of note is a simple techique I've been using for improving 
performance with a large numbers of  tests per evaluation - If I want a 
score out of 1000 tests then I initially just run the first 100 tests, 
if 100 is scroed then I go on a test against the next 100, and so on up 
to 1000. Thus I don't waste time performing 1000 tests on poor genomes. 
An alternative would be to keep testing until the first failed test, but 
I don;t think this is as good since the proportion of tests passed in 
the first 100 cases gives some idea of relative fitness between poor 
genomes - which is all of the genomes at the start of evolution.



Colin
